newsitem.title: USA: US lawmaker says working on encryption compromise.
newsitem.headline: US lawmaker says working on encryption compromise.

text.p: Senator Bob Kerrey said on Thursday he is crafting compromise legislation to resolve the heated debate over encryption export policy.
"There is an urgent need to change the law," the Nebraska Democrat said a news briefing here. "The market needs to develop and the market's going to be frustrated in trying to develop."

Encryption programs, which scramble information and render it unreadable without a password or software "key," have become a critical component of global communications and online commerce over the Internet.

But the Clinton administration sharply restricts the exports of products containing encryption, maintaining that the spread of strong encryption would thwart government efforts to catch spies and criminals.
To qualify for export under the current policy, strong encryption products must contain features allowing the government to crack the codes by getting access to the software keys.
Software companies contend the export limits are stifling their business while civil libertarians complain the rules could lead to unwarranted government snooping.
Several bills have already been introduced that would eliminate most of the export restrictions. But the bills have little chance of passage, Kerrey said.
Sen Kerrey said the new proposal would include some restriction on encryption, including possible import limits on encryption products produced outside of the United States.
But he emphasized that the restrictions would be aimed at outlawing the use of encryption in criminal activity, not commercial use of encryption.
"I would like to have as little commercial restriction as possible," he said.
Kerrey said he presently has only the "outline" of the bill, to be called the Secure Public Network Act of 1997. "A lot of the details have not been filled in," he said.

Kerrey said the goal in drafting the proposal would be to get the support of the Republican leadership and relevent committee chairman, including the Intelligence, Banking, Commerce and Judiciary chairmen. "This baby's got to have a lot of parents," he said.
Senate minority Leader Tom Daschle added his support to Kerrey's efforts.

"We have to make the Internet more secure and we have to ensure that security is something that becomes commonplace," Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, said at the briefing. "I would like to see us resolve this matter in this session of Congress, before the end of this year."
The Clinton administration was preparing its own legislation on encryption, but a draft of the proposal was sharply criticized by privacy advocates and industry groups.
Some said the legislation would have expanded the government's authority to listen to private communications without a warrant.
Kerrey said he would not support such a provision. "It's a bad idea," he said. "I think that was a legitimate concern expressed by opponents."
